poem:
### Orkney, First Light  

Dropped from books to sky,  
a Putney pint spun fate  
north. Fair Isle whispers  
sea and stone;  
a cook's hands stir  
more than soups—  
brewing tales in mist-  
kissed mornings.  
Youth's bold flight  
finds echoes  
in bird calls,  
in thresholds of  
forgotten worlds.  
Orkney's magic,  
woven into  
the artless air.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It’s more than a pretty backdrop’: crime writer Ann Cleeves on the magic of Orkney in Scotland Fifty years ago, I headed north for the first time. I’d dropped out of my university literature course – with the arrogance of youth, I thought I could read books anywhere. After a chance meeting in a Putney pub, I got a job as assistant cook in the Bird Observatory in Fair Isle. At that point, I didn’t". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
